title: Second deadly mosquito-borne virus detected in days
text:
Just days after Japanese encephalitis was detected for the first time this season in Victoria , a second mosquito-borne virus has reared its head across the border.

NSW Health said Kunjin virus had been detected at Cowra in the state's west.

The virus was found in a blood sample from a sentinel chicken on November 20, collected as part of NSW Health's routine surveillance.

A potentially deadly mosquito-borne virus has been detected in NSW. (Getty)

NSW Health's director of health protection Dr Stephen Conaty said the detections so early in the summer season were concerning.

"Mosquito numbers will likely increase with warmer weather, and we remind everyone in NSW to protect themselves against mosquito bites, which can cause diseases such as Japanese encephalitis and Murray Valley encephalitis, and infection with Kunjin virus, Ross River virus and Barmah Forest virus," Conaty said.

There are now 60 NSW LGAs that are considered to be higher risk of Japanese encephalitis virus.

READ MORE: Scorching heatwave to smother major city as hot air mass moves across state

A vaccine for JE is available and free for eligible people. (Getty)

Residents and travellers to these LGAs should take particular care to avoid mosquito bites.

"There is a safe, effective and free vaccine to protect against Japanese encephalitis (JE)," Conaty said.

"This vaccine is free to anyone who lives or routinely works in these 60 LGAs west of the dividing range and in northern NSW, and for people who work in some other high-risk occupations."

JE vaccine is available through general practitioners, Aboriginal health services and pharmacists.

People who meet the eligibility criteria should make an appointment ahead of time and let the provider know it is for the JE vaccine.

These providers may require a few days' notice so they can order the vaccine and may charge a consultation fee.

A booster dose may be recommended for some people with ongoing risk of exposure, one to two years after completing their primary course.

People are urged to use insect repellent. (Getty Images/iStockphoto)

Other than the JE vaccine, there is no vaccination or specific treatment for Kunjin virus or other mosquito-borne diseases in Australia.

Most people infected with Kunjin virus will suffer no symptoms.

Those who do may suffer fever, enlarged lymph nodes, rashes, swollen and aching joints, headaches, muscle weakness, and fatigue.

Those who do show symptoms should seek medical treatment immediately.

Severe infections can lead to lifelong neurological complications and even death.﻿

The best way to avoid infection is to avoid being bitten by mosquitoes, which are more active between dusk and dawn.

People can take actions such as applying insect repellent to exposed skin, wearing long sleeves and leggings with socks and covered footwear, and staying inside at dawn and dusk when mosquitoes are most active.﻿

Mosquito-borne diseases cannot be transmitted directly between humans or from any other animal.

Information on eligibility for a free JE vaccine is available online here .

Information on mosquito protection can be found here .﻿

title: Stark outlook for First Guardian investors as $336k Lamborghini, brewery sold
text:
L﻿iquidators of the company behind the collapsed superannuation fund First Guardian Master Trust are warning they face an unphill battle to recover hundreds of millions of dollars owed to investors.

First Guardian Master Trust entered liquidation this year, taking about $446 million from 6000 people with it.

Among them are business owners, parents and mum and dad investors, many of whom now face an uncertain financial future.

The Australian Securities and Investments Commission (ASIC) began investigating Falcon Capital in 2024. (Jim Rice)

In an update this week, liquidators from FTI Consulting said just $1.6 million has been recovered to date after they were appointed to manage First Guardian's responsible entity Falcon Capital.

Among that $1.6 million was ﻿$336,646 from the sale of a 2023 Lamborghini Urus and $450,000 from the liquidation of craft brewer Fox Friday Brewing.

Liquidators ﻿Ross Blakeley and Paul Harlond said "a substantial shortfall of asset recoveries to outstanding and unredeemed funds invested is likely".

They warned unitholders that "only a partial return of unredeemed funds may eventuate."

The report said many investments had been determined to be of no value.

Remaining investments are "largely illiquid, intangible assets, located in foreign jurisdictions, and involve related parties" of Falcon and First Guardian or parties that had links with those directors.

A 2023 Lamborghini Urus was sold for $336,646 as part of the recovery. (Lamborghini)

The liquidators said they have drawn up subpoenas for a list of more than 150 parties where Falcon monies are believed to have been paid.

However, the process was expected to take "considerable time" to finalise.﻿

Corporate regulator ASIC began investigating Falcon Capital, First Guardian and director David Anderson in late 2024.

According to ASIC, most of the 6000 investors accessed First Guardian through superannuation platforms Diversa, Netwealth and Equity Trustees.

It alleges investors were lured into transferring their super by "lead generators" who referred them to personal financial advice providers.

ASIC says they were "advised to roll their superannuation assets into a retail choice superannuation fund, and then invest into First Guardian".

title: Victorian government to slash 1000 jobs in brutal $4bn cost-cutting mission
text:
V﻿ictoria's public service sector will be heavily slashed by 1000 jobs as part of a desperate bid to strip back spending in the debt-riddled state.

The cuts will include 332 executive and senior jobs after the review discovered the workforce was too "top heavy" and recommended reducing the level of leadership roles.

It is expected the brutal cost-cutting measures will free up more than $4 billion over four years and the recommendations will be implemented immediately.

Around 330 executive and senior jobs will be axed from the state government﻿ as part of the Helen Silver review. (Simon Schluter)

The number of senior VPS5 and VPS6 positions will be reduced, saving an estimated $125 million over the forward estimates.

The Victorian government said it will rebalance the workforce back to pre-pandemic levels, which it claims will allow for more entry-level roles such as nurses, teachers and police officers.﻿

Nearly 30 government entities and boards will also be either wound down, merged or abolished, among them Sustainability Victoria, Cladding Safety Victoria, Victorian Marine and Coastal Council and the Road Safety Camera Commissioner And Reference Group.

VicHealth and Healthshare Victoria will also be folded ﻿into the Department of Health in a move to streamline public services following the forensic spending review.

The cuts will also limit spending on consultants and labour hire.﻿

"Victorian families are watching every dollar in their household budgets and they expect their government to do the same, and that is exactly what we are doing," Premier Jacinta Allan said today.

Allan said the cuts aim to help public service workers remain "laser-focussed" on services including education, healthcare, community safety and cost of living measures.

She said the Victorian government rejected some of the Silver recommendations which would have impacted frontline services.

READ MORE: Meta begins locking out Australian children from social media accounts

Allan said the state's public service sector is made up of "strong, professional" people. (Nine)

"I want to be clear today, not every recommendation has been accepted," Allan added.

"﻿We have not accepted them all because we do not want to cut into frontline services.

"The work we've been doing and the announcements we're making today are about continuing to keep the public service laser-focussed on continuing to deliver those services."

Allan acknowledged that the state's public service sector is made up of "strong, professional" people.﻿

"This is about looking at how we build our public sector for the future," Allan said.

The state avoided even deeper cuts after Treasurer Jaclyn Symes flagged that between 2000 to 3000 jobs could be lost when the $2 million Helen Silver review was commissioned back in February.

Victoria's p﻿ublic service industry comprised around 315,000 full-time staff as of June 2024.

title: Sand product recalled from Kmart and Target over asbestos fears
text:
Another play sand product for kids has been pulled from shelves around the country over asbestos fears.

A recall notice has been issued for the Make Your Own Unicorn Sand Ornament, sold at Kmart and Target.

The products contain loose, coloured play sand for children, and empty, unicorn-shaped ornaments.

The Make Your Own Unicorn Sand Ornament has been recalled from Kmart and Target. (Supplied)

The ACCC's product safety watchdog said the sand may include asbestos﻿, a prohibited substance in Australia.

"The products may cause a risk to health as asbestos has been detected in some samples after laboratory testing," the recall notice said.

However, the risk of any asbestos in the sand being either airborne or fine enough for inhalation is "low".

READ MORE: Meta begins locking out Australian children from social media accounts ﻿

The product was sold at Kmart and Target outlets. (Getty)

"Importantly, respirable asbestos has not been detected in any of the tested samples," the notice said.

"The release of respirable asbestos fibres is unlikely to occur in its current state, unless the sand is processed by mechanical means such as crushing or pulverising."

However, people are urged to stop using the product immediately, and follow the online guidelines for asbestos disposal .

They should also contact Kmart or Target for a full refund.

More details and the contact information for both chains can be found online here .﻿

title: Thailand eases alcohol ban to attract more tourists
text:
Thailand has temporarily eased a ban on the sale of afternoon alcoholic drinks in a move aimed to attract more tourists.

Restaurants, bottle shops and other authorised outlets can now sell beer, wine and spirits from 2pm to 5pm as part of a six-month trial, the BBC reports.

Overseas tourists, including Australians, have often been confused by the afternoon prohibition of alcohol sales ﻿in Thailand, a top destination for partygoers.

Tourists in Thailand will find buying an afternoon alcoholic drink easier after authorities eased a decades-old ban. (AP Photo/Sa (AP)

It was started in 1972, partly to deter public servants from drinking during work hours.

Alcohol sales in Thailand are now permitted from 11am to midnight during the next 180 days while an expert panel examines its impact.

Previously, breaking the ban carried the risk of a fine up to 10,000 baht﻿ ($437).

The change comes in the lead-up to the Christmas and the New Year holiday, both peak periods for tourists.﻿

New Thai Prime Minister Anutin Charnvirakul has pledged to kickstart the economy by reviving tourism following years of political unrest.

Local beer brands Chang and Singha are favourites among overseas visitors,﻿

About 800,000 Australians visit Thailand every year, according to Tourism Research Australia.﻿

title: Experts caution against taking medical advice from influencers
text:
Experts have called for greater governance on potentially misleading medical advice shared by influencers on social media.

Whilst over 40 per cent of young adults in the USA take advice from influencers, a report in The BMJ claims people are at risk of getting incorrect or biased information on important medical issues.

For example, Kim Kardashian encouraged her 360 million followers to have a full-body screening with magnetic resonance imaging.

READ MORE: ﻿ Scorching heatwave to smother major city as hot air mass moves across state

Kim Kardashian has previously promoted medical treaments with no proven benefits. (Getty)

While scans can have a benefit for people at a high-risk of certain conditions it is also linked to overdiagnosis and unnecessary medical interventions.

The fourth overlapping biases, according to the authors, include "limited expertise, industry influence, entrepreneurial interests, and personal belief.

"Such advice can cause psychological, physical, financial, and systemic harm," the report continued.

The report says influencers create a tight bond and relationship with their followers, with the sharing of real-life experiences helping foster a connection.

They can also help break stigmas surrounding certain medical conditions.

Lily Mae, also known as @chronicallylil on Instagram, documents her journey in navigating multiple medical conditions. (Instagram/@chronicallylil)

However, the report argues more government oversight is required to ensure influencers do not mislead their followers or promote unethical practices.

Australia already has some laws and regulations in place, banning paid health testimonials.

Some influencers believe medical experts should work more closely with them, believing they can bridge a key gap.

"I wish healthcare professionals would listen and engage more with patient communities online," Lily Mae, whose Instagram account @chronicallylil shows her struggles with Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, endometriosis, and vascular compression syndrome.

"There's such a wealth of firsthand knowledge being shared—real stories, symptoms, and lived experiences that could help improve care if more providers took the time to understand them."

title: Grant Hackett was on top of the world at age 20. This is what he wishes he'd known
text:
Exclusive: In this nine.com.au series, we'll be talking to some of Australia's smartest and sharpest ﻿entrepreneurs, founders and CEOs to find out what makes them tick - and what advice they'd have for anyone starting out.

Grant Hackett was just 20 when he won his first gold medal at the Sydney Olympics.

He scored another gold, three silver, and two bronze across his Olympic career, before trading his speedos for spreadsheets when he retired from swimming in 2008 and ﻿dove into the world of finance.

Grant Hackett was 20 when he won his first Olympic gold medal; now he's chief executive of Generation Development Group. (Eamon Gallagher/AFR)

Today, he is the chief executive of Generation Development Group and his achievements go far beyond how he performed in the pool in his 20s.

These are his secrets to success.

How do you start the day to set yourself up for success?

I always wake up at the same time, normally 5.15am every morning. The only time I don't do that is on the weekends, that's where I get my extra bit of recovery. I noticed that in my swimming career, when my sleep periods were different it just made me flat, so consistency of wake-up time is really important.

I have a series of drinks that I have, probably just because of my previous career. I've got a longevity mix, creatine, glutamine, amino acids ... and I have that pre-made the night before so I don't have to think about it in the morning, because I'm not a morning person.

Even though everyone thinks I should be because my former career, I hate early mornings, so I have to make it as easy as possible. I've also got a protein shake that's already set up, I have a water bottle, I'm really quite strict on all of that stuff.

I'll usually do a 45-minute workout in the morning and then the last thing I do after getting ready is always have breakfast with the kids. I'm not the person who tries to get to the office at 7am and get everything done, because I have really young kids and I always try to have breakfast with them.

That's my time at the table with them on weekdays and I feel quite sad when I don't get that time before I leave for work.

These days Hackett considers himself a 'corporate athlete' and some of his habits are holdovers from his swimming career. (Dallas Kilponen)

What are three daily habits you always stick to?

What I always do when I finish my work day is write a 'to do' list before I leave, which will be my first things to tick off the next day. I find that, for me, is an important way to disconnect from the office when I leave. If I don't do that, I'll leave being too analytical about everything else I've got to do and I won't slow down. That, for what I call the corporate athlete, is really important because if you don't get all those little things right like winding down, sleeping well, your cognitive capacity is just not as good.

I also always leave 15 minutes between meetings, because a lot of the time meetings go over and I want to give myself enough time to prepare mentally for the objectives of the next meeting. I don't like meetings for meetings' sake. I like to be really clear on what we're doing there, what we're trying to achieve, and what the actions are. So I always give myself 15 minutes in between each of those, and I always want an agenda for every meeting that I have too.

The other thing that I'm really, really conscious of as chief executive of a pretty large business is that your energy matters. Even if I'm having a rough day, like all of us do every now and again, I'm always very, very self-aware that the energy I bring in can really set the tone for a lot of other people. So I say good morning and make eye contact and ask how people's weekends were, because that stuff actually matters. It sounds like small talk but it's not, it's setting the energy and tone in the business.

Hackett made a massive career change from swimming to finance and admitted it wasn't easy. (AFR/Andrew Quilty)

Lots of Aussies are looking for a career change — what small action can help them get ahead of other candidates?

Develop relationships with people in a field that you're interested in, or at the very least people who are successful like serial entrepreneurs, because they will give you ideas and insights. I love it when someone comes to me and says, 'this is what I'm thinking about doing, I'd love your advice', or 'I'd love some help'.

And be willing to start at the bottom rung of the ladder. Be really, really willing to eat humble pie and start again.

I got day two into finance, this is going back nearly 20 years, and I could win World Championships and Olympics and break world records but I wasn't even the best at the table [in finance]. As soon as I realised that I was like, 'what do I need to do to get to the next level?'. I could have given up. I could have just gone and done talking gigs or other bits and pieces to generate income. I didn't need to be in a completely new field. But I was at the bottom rung of the ladder and recognised what I needed to do to get up that ladder, to get to a position that I feel really proud of. And as soon as you recognise that, you move up surprisingly quick.

What financial myth do you wish you never bought into?

In my teenage mind, when I started trading [stocks], I thought there was going to be two or three stocks that would be huge. I just thought, surely you pick a few winners and all of a sudden it's going to be worth millions of dollars.

That was probably the myth that was broken very, very quickly for me when I burned some cash on the dot com boom/bust. I realised pretty quick that there's no one stock that is a get rich quick scheme.

There are no shortcuts in anything I've done that's had some sort of success attributed to it, whether it's financial success, or in sport, or in business. You've got to be willing to do the hard work and maybe look like an overnight success eventually. But even the things that look like they grow quick, they're still really, really hard.

At 20, Hackett thought he 'knew everything'. He knows better now. (Dallas Kilponen)

What do you wish you could tell your 20-year-old self?

There's a few things that I probably couldn't put in this!

I would tell myself that when things are going really well, and you feel like you're winning, and life's good, it never lasts. So enjoy it, but recognise that nothing ever stays there.

And it's true for the opposite; when it hits the fan and things go really, really bad, and you feel like you're getting nowhere in life, and you've hit rock bottom ... it's never that bad. There's always an opportunity, and you can always get back to where you want to be if you're willing to do the work.

I think if I could tell 20-year-old self that I would have saved myself years of anxiety and ups and downs. But my 20 year-old-self thought he knew everything.

It's so funny, I remember I said my 20s that nothing could go wrong. Everything went right, I felt like life was easy. My 30s were the exact opposite – divorce, missing my kids, bad publicity. And then my 40s are when you actually start to get life ... it's a really nice stage of life.

Have you got a story? Contact reporter Maddison Leach at mleach@nine.com.au

title: How Australia's world-leading social media ban will be enforced
text:
Later this month, Australia will implement a world-first ban on social media for children , barring anyone aged under 16 from accessing certain websites and apps.

However, questions have been raised about how the ban will actually be enforced, and the government itself has admitted it won't be perfect in keeping underage users off the blocked sites.

This is what we know about how the ban will work.

Children younger than 16 will be banned from social media on December 10. (AP Photo/Rick Rycroft)

Who is responsible for keeping children off social media?

Responsibility for enforcing the ban, which comes into effect on December 10, has been placed on social media companies.

If children aged under 16 do find their way onto one of the banned sites, they and their parents won't face any penalties.

Instead, the federal government's eSafety agency can take action against tech companies that aren't taking "reasonable steps" to keep underage users off their platforms.

The list of age-restricted platforms includes Facebook, TikTok, and Reddit. (Getty)

What are those 'reasonable steps'?

eSafety hasn't specified exactly what social media companies need to do to avoid falling foul of the new laws.

"There is no one-size fits all approach for what constitutes the taking of reasonable steps," its regulatory guidance states.

In a nutshell, though, from December 10, providers need to deactivate or remove the accounts of users aged under 16, and stop those children from being able to immediately create new profiles to get around the ban.

This includes using geolocation data to check whether a user is an Australian resident, and verify that account holders are 16 or older.

While social media platforms can confirm ages by checking someone's government-issued ID, they're required to offer at least one alternative so users aren't forced to hand over their driver's licence or passport.

Social media companies like Meta are responsible for keeping underage users off their platforms. (AP Photo/Rick Rycroft)

Companies have already begun rolling out age assurance technology, which can estimate and infer someone's age.

The exact methods vary, but range from getting users to take a video selfie to analysing account behaviour and other metadata.

The government has acknowledged the ban won't be perfect and some children will get around it, but says it will have an overall positive impact.

"Just because there are under 18s who will drink alcohol today doesn't mean that it's not a good, important law that we have that you cannot drink under 18," Communications Minister Anika Wells said.

"This is about creating cultural change, and yeah, there's recalcitrance… we are creating a rule that everybody's off (social media), and the people that get around it, they will be the outliers."

Anika Wells has acknowledged some children will still manage to access social media despite the ban. (Kate Geraghty)

There's also a range of requirements for companies around the data they collect, making sure they don't discriminate against diverse groups, and that users have an avenue to appeal decisions made against them.

The full eSafety guidance can be found here .

What happens if social media companies don't enforce the ban?

If a social media company breaks the age restriction laws, including by failing to take reasonable steps to keep underage children off its platforms, it will face a fine of up to $49.5 million.

eSafety can also take the offending company to court to seek injunctions or undertakings from it in response to any breach.

title: The one state where this could cop you double demerits year round
text:
Double demerits will soon come into effect for the Christmas holidays, but not all Australian states and territories enforce them equally.

Some impose double demerits year-round, while others opt out entirely – though drivers from some states can still cop double demerit penalties across borders.

Here's when and where ﻿double demerits will be enforced over the 2025 Christmas holidays.

READ MORE: Australia Post reveals deadline for mailing Christmas parcels

D﻿ouble demerits are on the way for NSW, the ACT and WA ahead of the holidays. (Getty)

NSW, the ACT and WA

NSW, the ACT and WA impose double demerits over most holiday periods and long weekends, including:

the Christmas and New Year period

Australia Day

Easter

Anzac Day﻿

King's Birthday

Labour Day

state-specific public holidays (e.g. WA Day)﻿

Double demerits only apply to specific road offences.

In NSW, they are: speeding, using a mobile phone while driving, riding without a helmet, not wearing or incorrectly wearing a seatbelt (drivers and passengers).

NSW drivers can cop double demerits if their passengers aren't wearing a seatbelt correctly. (9News)

The same rules apply in the ACT, and a few additional offences are subject to double demerits in WA.

They are: ﻿﻿drink or drug driving, running a red light, driving a vehicle fitted with a device designed to evade detection by a speed camera, and driving in a manner to evade detection by a speed camera.

Double demerits will be enforced on the following dates over the Christmas holidays:

NSW: December 24 to January 4

ACT: December 24 to January 4

WA: December 19 to January 4

Queensland

﻿Queensland also imposes double demerits, though in a slightly different way.

Instead of limiting double demerits to holiday periods, they are enforced year-round ﻿and apply to motorists who repeatedly commit specific offences.

These offences include:

﻿speeding more than 20km/h over the speed limit

mobile phone offences

driver seatbelt offences

seatbelt offences for passengers under 16

motorcycle helmet offences

READ MORE: How to maximise public holidays and make the most of your annual leave in 2026

Double demerits apply year-round in Queensland. (Getty)

Drivers will have double demerits applied if they're caught repeating an offence from the same offence group two or more times within a year.

For example, a driver caught on their phone will receive double demerits if they are caught using it a second or subsequent time within 12 months.

Victoria, SA, NT and Tasmania﻿

Unlike ﻿the other states, Victoria, SA, NT and Tasmania﻿ don't impose double demerits at all.

But that doesn't mean drivers are totally in the clear.

Motorists who hold a Queensland licence could still cop double demerits if they're caught committing an eligible offence in another state or territory.

That's because Queensland drivers ﻿who commit demerit-point offences interstate are subject to the demerit points that apply in their home state for the same offence.

The same goes for drivers from NSW, ﻿who are also subject to double demerits in their home state if they're caught breaking the rules across state lines.

title: Leading groups for UK women and girls to close doors for trans women
text:
Transgender women will no longer be allowed to join two of the UK's leading groups for women and girls, in the aftermath of a Supreme Court ruling.

If you or anyone you know needs help: Transcend Australia (Supporting Australian families and their trans, gender diverse and non-binary children and young people).

Kids Helpline on 1800 551 800

The Women's Institute and Girlguiding announced the changes within days of each other, noting the difficulty of their respective decisions.

In April, the Supreme Court ruled that a woman was someone born biologically female, excluding transgender people from the legal definition.

This judgment related to whether a trans woman with a gender recognition certificate (GRC), a formal document that gives legal recognition of someone's new gender, was protected from discrimination as a woman under Britain's Equality Act.

Both groups said their recent decisions were made with legal advice, and in the case of the Women's Institute, the group said the judgment meant it could "no longer legally offer formal membership to transgender women".

Women celebrate the April Supreme Court ruling. ( )

"As an organisation that has proudly welcomed transgender women into our membership for more than 40 years, this is not something we would do unless we felt that we had no other choice," The Women's Institute CEO Melissa Green said.

She said the organisation would continue to support trans women outside of formal membership.

The move was made with a "heavy heart", according to a joint statement from the Girlguiding heads.

"This is a decision we would have preferred not to make, and we know that this may be upsetting for members of our community," it read, noting adult helper roles were still open to all.

Both statements can be read in full below:

Girlguiding From Chair of Trustees Denise Wilson, CEO Felicity Oswald, and Chief Guide Tracy Foster: Following April's Supreme Court decision relating to sex and gender, many organisations across the country have been facing complex decisions about what it means for girls and women and for the wider communities affected. Girlguiding's governing charity documents set out that the membership and people who benefit from our organisation are girls and women. The Supreme Court ruled that girls and women are defined in the Equality Act 2010 by their biological sex at birth. Following detailed considerations, expert legal advice and input from senior members, young members and our Council, the Board of Trustees for Girlguiding has made the difficult decision that Girlguiding must change, following the Supreme Court's ruling. From today, 2 December, it is with a heavy heart that we are announcing trans girls and young women will no longer be able to join Girlguiding. This is a decision we would have preferred not to make, and we know that this may be upsetting for members of our community. There will be no immediate changes for current young members, but more information will be shared next week. Most adult roles, including unit helpers, district helpers and administrative support, are already open to all, so we are confident that no volunteers will have to leave the organisation. Girlguiding believes strongly in inclusion, and we will continue to support young people and adults in marginalised groups. Over the next few months, we will explore opportunities to champion this value and actively support young people who need us. A new taskforce will explore ways to support everyone and create new opportunities. Members of all ages are encouraged to contribute to this taskforce to help us shape a future organisation that is inclusive. Girlguiding is proud to be the UK's largest youth organisation dedicated to girls and is focused on creating an equal world for girls and young women. For over 100 years, we have been a welcoming space for all girls to have new experiences, support their communities, build friendships and grow their confidence. While Girlguiding may feel a little different going forward, these core aims and principles will always endure and we remain committed to treating everyone with dignity and respect, particularly those from marginalised groups that have felt the biggest impact of this decision. The Women's Institute From CEO Melissa Green: It is with the utmost regret and sadness that we must announce that, from April 2026, we can no longer offer formal membership to transgender women. As an organisation that has proudly welcomed transgender women into our membership for more than 40 years, this is not something we would do unless we felt that we had no other choice. To be able to continue operating as the Women's Institute — a legally recognised women's organisation and charity — we must act in accordance with the Supreme Court's judgment and restrict formal membership to biological women only. However, this change is only in respect to our membership policy and does not change our firm belief that transgender women are women. We know that many of our members will find this decision extremely painful. We have been actively seeking alternative ways — outside of formal membership — of continuing to extend fellowship, sisterhood, and support to transgender women, who have been such an important part of our WI family. In April 2026, we will be launching a national network of local WI Sisterhood groups, which will offer monthly opportunities for all people, including transgender women, to come together to socialise, learn from each other, and share their experiences of living as women. Our activity outside of formal membership has always and will continue to play a vital role in creating welcoming spaces where all women can come together to learn, share ideas, and work together to improve lives in our communities. We remain absolutely committed to delivering on that mission.

Move may be influenced by anti-trans campaigners

The interpretation of the ruling has been disputed by legal advocacy group Good Law Project, which says the law does not "require trans exclusion".

In the case of Girlguiding, the GRC is only available to over-18s.

Good Law Project's trans rights lead, Jess O'Thomson, believed the move came after intense lobbying from "anti-trans campaigners".

UK court rules a woman is defined by the gender at birth The court upheld an appeal by a campaign group on whether transgender women are legally women under equality legislation.

In 2018, anti-trans group Fair Play for Women launched a petition asking Girlguiding to review its policy for trans members.

"They thought after the Supreme Court decision in April that the whole world would suddenly agree with them," O'Thomson said, of trans opponents.

" But they have misunderstood the law, as well as human nature. "

The legal charity said it was prepared to offer legal and financial backing to organisations willing to challenge the ruling's interpretation.

Exclusion a 'cruelty', advocates say

Helen Belcher, CEO of TransActual, a leading UK transgender advocacy group, said charities could not afford to fight legal claims surrounding the ruling's interpretation.

She added the decisions would have an innumerable impact on Britain's "beloved charities and national institutions".

"Our thoughts are with the people who may be outed by their exclusion, or lose access to their vital social groups and support networks at a time when those are more important than ever," she said.

"This government must be held responsible for the long-lasting damage they are doing to a generation of LGBTQ+ people.

" This is mere cruelty to exclude trans people from doing the things they love with the people who love them. "

Counter-protesters mocked JK Rowling at an anti-trans demonstration in April. ( )

Around 41 per cent of trans individuals in the UK say they have experienced a hate crime due to their gender identity, according to the latest statistics on the prevalence.

Leading anti-trans campaigner and author JK Rowling said the Girlguiding announcement would "help girls".

"It reminds girls that the desires of boys do not supersede their feelings, their rights, their discomfort or their safety," she said on X.

Campaign group For Women Scotland (FWS), which is financially backed by Rowling, spearheaded the April appeal that determined whether transgender women were legally women under equality legislation.

title: Legendary guitarist and songwriter Steve Cropper dies aged 84
text:
Steve Cropper, the guitarist and songwriter who helped anchor the celebrated Memphis backing band Booker T and the MG's, has died aged 84.

The musician also co-wrote the classics Green Onions, (Sittin' on) The Dock of the Bay and In the Midnight Hour.

Pat Mitchell Worley, president and CEO of the Soulsville Foundation, said Mr Cropper's family told her that he died in Nashville on Wednesday. The foundation operates the Stax Museum of American Soul Music in Memphis, located at the site of the former Stax Records, where Cropper worked for years.

The cause of death was not immediately known.

Longtime associate Eddie Gore said: "He's such a good human."

"We were blessed to have him, for sure," he added.

The guitarist, songwriter and record producer was not known for flashy playing, but his spare, catchy licks and solid rhythm chops helped define Memphis soul music.

'Play it, Steve!'

Steve Cropper's very name was immortalised in the 1967 smash Soul Man, recorded by Sam & Dave.

Midway through the track singer Sam Moore calls out, "Play it, Steve," as Cropper pulls off a tight, ringing riff, a slide sound that Cropper used a Zippo lighter to create.

The exchange was re-enacted in the late 1970s when Cropper joined the John Belushi-Dan Aykroyd act The Blues Brothers and played on their hit cover of Soul Man.

Rolling Stones guitarist Keith Richards, asked once about Cropper: said simply: "Perfect, man."

Steve Cropper performs with the Blues Brothers Band in Washington in 2016. (AP: Andrew Harnik)

Steve Cropper was inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame in 1992 as a member of Booker T and the MG's.

Rolling Stone magazine ranked him 39th on its 100 Greatest Guitarists list, describing him as "the secret ingredient in some of the greatest rock and soul songs".

The guitarist was in the 1980 movie The Blues Brothers and its follow-up, Blues Brothers 2000, portraying The Colonel in the Blues Brothers band. In real life, he toured with them.

He was inducted into the Songwriters Hall of Fame in 2005, and two years later received a Grammy Award for lifetime achievement.

Cropper continued recording into his later years, including 2024's Friendlytown, which was nominated for a Grammy. Earlier this year, Cropper received the Tennessee Governor's Arts Award, the state's highest honour in the arts.

AP

title: Former NT administrator, musician and author Ted Egan dies aged 93
text:
Folk music legend, author and former Northern Territory Administrator Ted Egan has died aged 93.

Egan died this morning at home in his beloved outback hometown of Alice Springs.

The singer, who was famous for his larger-than-life persona and for popularising the beer carton as a musical instrument, was surrounded by his large family when he died.

He was also known as a vocal supporter of Aboriginal land rights during the 1960s and 1970s, including penning the song Gurindji Blues with former Australian of the Year Galarrwuy Yunupingu.

In a statement, his wife Nerys Evans and son Greg Egan told the ABC he "lived a big and very generous life spanning 93 years. We will miss him enormously".

"It is with sadness but also great pride that Nerys Evans and the Egan family mark the passing of our beloved partner, father, grandfather, great grandfather and best mate," they said.

"Ted passed peacefully at home this morning, as was his wish.

"We shared Ted with Territorians, Australians and the wider world."

title: Versace excelled at maximalism. Now Prada wants to take it further
text:
One of the biggest rivalries in fashion is over, with Prada buying fellow Italian fashion house Versace in a billion-dollar deal.

The takeover, worth 1.25 billion euro ($2.2 billion), was confirmed in a chic, one-line statement.

Versace's fortunes have been waning in recent years as the nearly 50 year old brand struggles to capture consumers as it once did.

Prada, on the other hand, has found immense success, thanks in part to its more youthful label, Miu Miu — its name derived from its owner, Miuccia Prada.

Gianni Versace backstage with supermodels Karen Mulder, Linda Evangelista and Carla Bruni in 1992. (Getty Images: Foc Kan/WireImage)

In March, Donatella Versace stepped down as creative director, nearly three decades after she took up the role following the assassination of her brother and the brand's founder, Gianni Versace.

She was replaced by former Miu Miu head Dario Vitale — though executives say his move was unrelated to the Prada deal.

Now, with a new owner, Versace will be hoping to be brought back into style.

Cultural headwinds

When it comes to fashion, Prada and Versace could not be more different.

"They're kind of polar opposites," said Kirstie Clements, the former editor of Vogue Australia, adding Versace had always been "dynamic".

"If you go back to when it was designed by Gianni Versace, [it was] really bright, colourful, sexy, in your face, glitzy," she told ABC News.

"But not over the top because he always had a sense of restraint."

Versace is synonymous with bold patterns, glitzy embellishments and seductive silhouettes. (Reuters: Stefano Rellandini)

Alternatively, Prada is a "more intellectual brand", said Clements, with its aesthetic not being overtly sexy.

" They're both very representative of Italian fashion, but super different. "

Prada's latest collection featured the brand's signature clean lines and a subdued color palette. (Reuters: Alessandro Garofalo/File Photo)

According to The Australian Financial Review's fashion editor Lauren Sams, Versace's struggles in recent years can be attributed to a post-pandemic economy, but also "cultural headwinds".

"I think it says a lot when Palazzo Versace, the hotel attached to the fashion brand, that when it opened in Australia, it opened on the Gold Coast and that was the perfect spot for it," she told ABC News Channel.

"It was a place where you could be outsized and sexy and outrageous, and that is what Versace is.

"That is not really sort of the time at the moment. We are not really having that moment in fashion."

A mini skirt with maximum impact

In 2022, a very short skirt by Miu Miu became one of the most coveted pieces in the industry.

Debuted on the runway the previous season, the pleated, eye-poppingly low-slung mini skirt captured the attention of the front row — and soon after, the rest of the internet.

This skirt from Miu Miu was a hit with industry insiders, influencers and celebrities alike. (Getty Images: Vanni Bassetti)

The mini skirt was seen on Zendaya, Emma Corrin and Emily Ratajkowski, to name a few.

But no-one sparked more headlines than Nicole Kidman who, at 54, wore the matching set on the cover of Vanity Fair, later saying she "begged" stylists to let her wear the viral outfit.

Nicole Kidman was one of many celebrities to wear the viral outfit. (Supplied: Vanity Fair)

"Prada has had its 'on seasons' and its 'off seasons', but it's had a lot of publicity through Miu Miu," Clements said.

"It did that little belt skirt. All the influencers were wearing it. It's all about getting a viral moment."

Dario Vitale debuted his first Versace season in September, with the spring/summer 2026 collection during Milan Fashion Week.

Dario Vitale's debut collection with the brand paid tribute to Gianni Versace. (Instagram: @Versace)

The collection referenced the brand's 1980s Gianni Versace era, with critics calling it everything from bold and brash to fun and audacious.

"If you look at that collection, it's really different and it was very divisive. Not everybody loved it," Clements said.

"But when I looked at it I thought, 'That's interesting, that's a move forward,' because I think Versace was stuck."

Made in Italy

Versace was previously owned by US luxury group Capri Holdings.

Now, under Prada, it's going back to its roots.

"'Made in Italy' is a really important designation for Italian designers and I think bringing it back into an Italian company is going to be a really important part of its future," Sams said.

A look from one of Donatella Versace’s final collections during her time as creative director. (AP: Antonio Calanni)

But in Clements opinion, Prada still has "a lot of work to do" in order to make Versace profitable.

"Do they buy something else? Do they buy Armani? Are they going to turn into an Italian conglomerate?" she said.

"It's quite a tricky time in fashion. They're looking for brands that have a solid philosophy like Versace does."

Prada is not yet on the level of luxury goods conglomerate LVMH, which owns 75 brands including Louis Vuitton, Christian Dior, and Moët & Chandon.

How Anna Wintour redefined fashion over almost 40 years As US Vogue editor-in-chief, Anna Wintour forever changed the fashion industry.

But Clements said Prada's purchase of Versace could be the beginnings of an Italian luxury group that could one day rival French luxury group Kering, which owns Gucci, Saint Laurent, Bottega Veneta and Alexander McQueen.

Trends come and go, and come back again — so will Versace rise to the occasion once again?

"100 per cent, if you get it all right," Clements said.

"If you get the right celebrities, the right influencers, the right people on board — and it's the right clothing for the moment — you can do it.

title: People with disability 'blossom like a flower' on community radio
text:
Across Australia, community radio stations act as hubs of culture and connection, reflecting the diversity of the communities they serve, powered by a legion of loving volunteers.

At 8CCC Radio in Alice Springs, the voices of people with disability are put centrestage — or desk — and broadcast onto the FM airwaves, blasting into local cars or kitchens, and online all over the world.

8CCC broadcasts across central Australia and the Barkly. (ABC News: Xavier Martin)

Unassuming, 8CCC sits next to the fish and chippy and a Chinese restaurant, with a coffee shop out the front and a place to sit and listen. The station brings people of all abilities and backgrounds together to share music and stories.

The outback station became a National Disability Insurance Scheme (NDIS) training provider a few years ago, and since that time, it has grown the number of shows presented by people with disability on the station to five.

Ben Russell, who lives with a vision impairment, loves hosting the anime show on 8CCC Community Radio. (ABC News: Elsie Lange)

What is community radio?

Operated by and for local communities, these stations exist all over the country and are integral not only to the ecosystem of media in Australia, but to the arts too.

They are non-profit organisations, giving much-needed airtime to voices and content that can be missed out in traditional mainstream media.

8CCC Radio started in Alice Springs in 1981 and started broadcasting into Tennant Creek in 1990, and sits alongside its local sister station, Central Australian Aboriginal Media Association (CAAMA).

Mark Bensted from disability support service Total Recreation has been a part of Andy Harrison's journey on 8CCC. (ABC News: Xavier Martin)

According to the Community Broadcasting Association of Australia (CBAA), there are nearly 5.3 million Australians tuning into community radio across the country every week.

CBAA director of public affairs Reece Kinnane said the sector came together two years ago to put together a plan to focus on what makes community radio unique and different.

"We want to provide a space for all Australians to connect and we want to be a part of all Australian communities, and that includes people with a disability," Mr Kinnane said.

"It's really important that people with a disability hear stories told with a lens of lived experience … a lot of stations are stepping up to do that and it's fantastic to see."

Accessibility opens doors

Andy Harrison lives with a physical disability and has been presenting on 8CCC for five years. He now presents the afternoon program every weekday and is known for his tough interview style and love of country music.

Andy Harrison says he loves playing country music on his show. (ABC News: Xavier Martin)

"Me being an ambassador for disability like I am, [being on 8CCC] gave me the opportunity to put the word out to other young people and say, 'Hey, if you want to get your own show started, come down to 8CCC,'" Mr Harrison said.

" We'll train you up and get your own show going, and now we've got up to four or five broadcasters with disabilities running on 8CCC five days a week. "

Mr Harrison said it was station manager Benjamin Erin who offered him a paid, full-time role at the station after years of volunteering had honed his skills.

Benjamin Erin says it's important that the voices heard on community radio reflect the community. (ABC News: Xavier Martin)

"Being accessible to Andy opened up the doors to being accessible to the broader community," Mr Erin said.

He said partnering with local disability service provider Total Recreation helped the station to have more people with diverse abilities volunteer and participate.

"While many of our shows are shows about general things that anyone could be interested in, [because they are] presented by someone who happens to have a disability, there are unique perspectives that come from making sure those voices can be part of those conversations," he said.

Royston Thompson presents a sports show on 8CCC. (ABC News: Elsie Lange)

Space to 'blossom like a flower'

While Mr Harrison's program welcomes a diverse range of guests including local musicians and politicians, Ben Russell, who is vision-impaired, hosts an hour-long show talking about anime.

Ben Russell says he loves that 8CCC is making sure the voices of people with disability are heard. (ABC News: Elsie Lange)

Mr Russell said having the platform to present his show made him feel he was "able to achieve something".

"[To] prove to people that people with disabilities actually have a chance in this world, to show them what it means to blossom like a flower," Mr Russell said.

Jaidyn Stanton said he felt like "a kid in a candy store" when he chose the rock music he was going to blast into the world that week for his show, Jaidyn's Rock Nation.

Right now, his show is focused on rock music from the 1970s, and he said he loved interviewing local musicians on air.

Jaidyn Stanton hosts a weekly rock show at the station. (ABC News: Elsie Lange)

Mr Stanton's penchant for presenting started back in high school, when he did an internship at another commercial radio station in Alice Springs and received warm praise from his teachers at the time.

And his listeners mean the world to him.

"I just want to give a shout-out to all my rock-loving brothers and sisters out there who actually love tuning into my show every week," Mr Stanton said.

"We love community radio."

title: What's in pregnancy supplements? Sorting science from marketing spin
text:
Navigating pregnancy and early parenting advice can be overwhelming — and for many parents, the confusion begins in the supplement aisle.

One of the first things women planning a pregnancy or in the early stages of one are advised to do is take a prenatal supplement containing folic acid — the synthetic version of folate, or vitamin B9 — and iodine.

Iodine is essential for a baby's brain and nervous system development, while folate is particularly important in early pregnancy to help prevent neural tube defects such as spina bifida.

But there are scores of supplements to choose from, many of which contain a plethora of vitamins and minerals, sometimes in vastly different amounts.

Adding to the confusion is the fact many newer supplement companies substitute folic acid with methylfolate — a lesser-studied form of folate, often claimed to be more easily absorbed — and usually at heftier prices.

"It's very hard standing in the pharmacy to negotiate those claims, to understand what is effective, what is cost-effective, and what is safe," Alexis Shub, obstetrician and maternal fetal medicine specialist at the Mercy Hospital for Women, said.

So what ingredients are essential in a prenatal supplement? And when should you start taking one?

What supplements are recommended in pre-conception and pregnancy?

National pregnancy care guidelines recommended women take 400–600 micrograms of folic acid per day ideally from four weeks before conception and throughout the first 12 weeks of pregnancy.

For women at increased risk of having a pregnancy affected by neural tube defects — such as those with a family history, or who have diabetes — a higher dose (5 milligrams per day) may be recommended.

Folic acid supplementation substantially reduces the risk of neural tube defects, but does not prevent all cases. (Pexels: MART PRODUCTION)

When it comes to iodine, all women are advised to take a daily supplement containing 150 micrograms when they're planning a pregnancy, pregnant and breastfeeding. (Women with a pre-existing thyroid disorder should seek medical advice first.)

If you haven't taken a supplement prior to conception — and it's estimated half of all pregnancies in Australia are unplanned — it's recommended you start once you become aware you're pregnant.

To reduce the risk of nutrient deficiencies and neural tube defects across the population, bread products in Australia are also fortified with folic acid and iodine. Since mandatory fortification was introduced in 2009, neural tube defects have fallen by 14 per cent.

What's the difference between folic acid and other types of folate?

When you consume folate through food or folic acid, your body converts it into methylfolate (also known as L-5-methyltetrahydrofolate or 5-MTHF). It does this with the help of an enzyme made by the MTHFR gene.

In recent years, a growing number of supplement companies have developed prenatal formulations that contain methylfolate instead of folic acid.

Typically, they're promoted as being more "bioavailable" (or easier to absorb) and therefore a better choice, especially for people with MTHFR gene variations, which can slightly reduce the gene's effectiveness.

Tests to consider if you're planning pregnancy Government guidelines recommend seeing a GP three to six months before you become pregnant.

But Shelley Wilkinson, a prenatal dietitian and an obstetric medicine researcher at the University of Queensland, said that wasn't the case, and stressed that folic acid was the only form of folate that had been shown in trials to help prevent neural tube defects.

"The majority of people will be able to get the folate they need from [folic acid] supplements and food," Dr Wilkinson said.

Australian pregnancy guidelines (and other international health authorities) note that pregnant women with MTHFR variations — which are estimated to affect 60–70 per cent of the population — can still process all types of folate, including folic acid.

According Dr Shub: "When people look at blood levels of folate in women with MTHFR variants, they're the same when they've taken folic acid as women who don't have that mutation."

It shouldn't be assumed, she said, that methylfolate supplements — which are typically more expensive — work in the same way as folic acid to support neural tube development.

"The data around neural tube defect prevention is all with folic acid … so for women who take other variants [of folate], we just don't have that information.

"The other problem with [methylfolate] is that it's not as stable … it's susceptible to changes to light and temperature, and so what you think you're getting in your vitamin might not be what's actually in there."

Folic acid intake is more important for determining blood folate levels than having a MTHFR variant, health authorities say. (Getty Images: Galina Zhigalova)

Claire Roberts, who leads the Pregnancy Health and Beyond Laboratory at Flinders University, said while supplements containing methylfolate were "likely" to help to prevent neural tube defects, and may even be beneficial for some women, there wasn't enough evidence to confirm that.

What about other vitamins and minerals?

Vitamin D testing during pregnancy used to be recommended, as was supplementation for women found to be deficient, but Australia's national pregnancy care guidelines were recently updated to advise against this.

The guidelines note that while routine vitamin D supplementation during pregnancy "may offer some benefit", there's insufficient evidence to recommend testing or supplementation as part of standard pregnancy care.

When it comes to supplementing other key vitamins and minerals, the guidelines currently recommend:

Calcium : recommended for women at risk of high blood pressure

: recommended for women at risk of high blood pressure Iron : recommended for pregnant women based on blood test results at 28 weeks

: recommended for pregnant women based on blood test results at 28 weeks Vitamin B6 : not enough evidence to detect clinical benefits in pregnancy, though it may help to reduce nausea (high doses, however, can lead to serious adverse outcomes — see below)

: not enough evidence to detect clinical benefits in pregnancy, though it may help to reduce nausea (high doses, however, can lead to serious adverse outcomes — see below) Vitamin B12 : not enough evidence to draw conclusions, though it may benefit women who are vegetarian or vegan

: not enough evidence to draw conclusions, though it may benefit women who are vegetarian or vegan Magnesium : not routinely recommended

: not routinely recommended Omega-3 fatty acids : may reduce the risk of preterm birth in women who are low in omega-3

: may reduce the risk of preterm birth in women who are low in omega-3 Vitamin A and E : high-dose supplementation not routinely recommended for pregnant women with no identified deficiency or clinical need

: high-dose supplementation not routinely recommended for pregnant women with no identified deficiency or clinical need Vitamin C : high-dose supplementation not routinely recommended for pregnant women with adequate dietary intake

: high-dose supplementation not routinely recommended for pregnant women with adequate dietary intake Zinc : guideline under review

: guideline under review Other minerals (e.g. selenium) : not enough evidence to draw conclusions

: not enough evidence to draw conclusions Probiotics: guideline under review.

With the exception of folic acid and iodine, Dr Shub said there was limited evidence for many of the ingredients in prenatal supplements, and that for the majority of pregnant women (without risk factors or known deficiencies), a balanced diet would provide most of the nutrients they needed.

"If women are trying to do the best thing in their pregnancy, a healthy diet and exercise is still the best way to go. Although that can be difficult, spending money on [multi]vitamins is probably not a good use of money."

Getting vitamins and minerals through a varied, wholefood diet offers benefits that can't be obtained from supplements, experts say. (Pexels: Kei Scampa)

Dr Wilkinson agreed: "There's a lot you can get from a well-planned diet — omega-3, so DHA and EPA [two types of omega-3 fatty acids] can be obtained, and choline [a nutrient important for fetal development] … is in meat, fish, poultry, dairy, eggs, green leafy veggies, legumes, and potatoes."

Evidence for choline supplementation is mixed, though some experts suggest it may help women meet their recommended daily intake.

Dr Wilkinson acknowledged that many Australians struggled to get enough fruit and vegetables in their diet, and encouraged pregnant women concerned about their nutrient intake to work with an accredited dietitian or their healthcare provider to create a "food-first approach".

" Eating a nourishing diet is going to be more important than finding the 'right' supplement. "

Why more is not always better

Dr Wilkinson said while many women took pregnancy supplements containing a range of vitamins and minerals for "peace of mind", there was a risk of consuming too much, particularly if women were taking a combination of products.

"We've seen it with vitamin B6, which can be in magnesium [supplements], energy drinks, multivitamins and morning sickness tablets."

She said she had seen some pregnant women who were taking more than 50 times the recommended daily amount of vitamin B6, which in high doses can cause irreversible nerve damage.

Australia's national medicines regulator recently reported that high doses of B6 could lead to adverse pregnancy outcomes, particularly in the first trimester.

Dr Wilkinson recommends using a supplement that contains folic acid and iodine at the recommended dose. (Pexels: Nataliya Vaitkevich)

High doses of vitamin A, C and E can also be dangerous during pregnancy: "It's why women should not take non-pregnancy multivitamins," Dr Shub said.

Unnecessarily high doses of recommended vitamins can also pose potential health risks, said Professor Roberts, whose research has found a link between excess maternal folate levels and a rise in gestational diabetes.

"It's almost like there is a sweet spot — too little is not good, and too much is not good," she said.

In a small 2023 study, Dr Wilkinson and her colleagues found 5 per cent of pregnant women exceeded the safe upper level of intake for folic acid (1,000 micrograms per day), and almost 50 per cent exceeded the upper limit for iron.

While folic acid supplementation is only recommended during the first trimester, research suggests many women continue to take it in the second and third trimesters as part of a prenatal multivitamin.

Dr Wilkinson said this was generally OK, given daily folate requirements were increased during pregnancy, but advised women against taking "large amounts" that might put their daily consumption above the recommended upper limit.

Calls for better regulation and labelling

Unlike registered medicines, most vitamin supplements in Australia aren't evaluated by the Therapeutic Goods Administration before they hit the market.

The TGA regulates the safety and quality of AUST L products by limiting them to use only pre-approved low-risk ingredients, however many are not assessed for efficacy, placing them in a regulatory "grey area", Dr Wilkinson said.

ABC Health in your Instagram feed Follow @abchealth on Instagram, where we're busting myths and sharing practical, smart health advice.

She and Professor Roberts said they'd like to see increased regulation of prenatal supplements to help consumers make evidence-based choices.

"Women want to do the best thing for their baby, and they have an awful lot of guilt if they don't," Professor Roberts said.

Dr Wilkinson added that increased oversight could help women avoid paying for products they didn't need.

"It could be a lot cheaper and easier if you took what you needed, rather than what you're marketed."

title: Outback opal miners allowed to operate in new national park
text:
Miners with tenures inside one of Queensland's newest national parks will be allowed to continue hunting for opals.

Vergemont Station was bought by the state government in April last year, backed by an anonymous $21 million donation.

The purchase led to months of uncertainty for opal miners with tenures inside the former cattle station, which is larger than the Australian Capital Territory.

Individual mining operations on Vergemont are small in scale. (ABC Western Qld: Hannah Walsh)

But the decision now by the state government to retain and expand an area of land declared in 1991 for opal miners — Restricted Area 257 — has been welcomed by the industry.

"It's pure relief," Boulder Opal Association secretary Alison Summerville said.

" I've made several phone calls today to particular families who have been waiting on tenterhooks and it's a wonderful Christmas present for all of us. "

Ms Summerville said many people feared the national park designation would force generational miners out of the leases they held on Vergemont.

Minister for Natural Resources and Mines Dale Last said it showed the government's commitment to backing the resources sector, including small-scale opal miners.

This boulder opal found on Vergemont is valued at $300,000. (ABC Western Qld: Hannah Walsh)

"The change of government was a significant factor in retaining this industry for the future," Ms Summerville said.

The government said the acquisition of Vergemont Station and the nearby former stations of Tonkoro and Melrose would create a corridor of protected land to safeguard habitat and rare and threatened species, along with significant Indigenous cultural heritage.

Environment Minister Andrew Powell said the park was part of a plan to add 1.8 million hectares to the state's protected areas by 2028.

"The proposed new national park will safeguard the significant ecological values of the unique landscape," Mr Powell said.

The department also confirmed new park rangers had been employed to manage the former station and other protected areas in the region.

Threatened species like the night parrot and purple-necked rock wallaby live on Vergemont. (Supplied: Qld Government)

Miners ecstatic

Opal miner Robbie Vinnicombe, who has combed through the red dirt of Vergemont for the past 30 years, said the outcome was a huge relief.

"I feel ecstatic, I'm shaking," he said.

"For me personally, it means my investment is no longer sitting on a knife's edge.

" I've invested my life, my life's savings and time, and up until recently with the purchase of Vergemont it was all put on hold and I had no idea where we were standing. "

Robbie Vinnicombe has hunted for opals on Vergemont for three decades. (ABC Western Qld: Hannah Walsh)

There were 60 active mining tenures and 80 sub-blocks under exploration on Vergemont at the time of its purchase.

"It's a very good outcome not just for the industry but for our region," My Vinnicombe said.

The opal industry contributes $14 million a year to Winton, according to a report commissioned by the town's local council.

The Vergemont camp site has hosted generations of opal miners. (ABC Western Qld: Hannah Walsh)

The fine print

Ms Summerville said everyone who had a mining tenure within the Restricted Area 257 was "safe".

"Every single piece of mining tenure, whether it was a mining claim, a mining lease or an EPM [exploration permit for minerals] has been retained and will be retained for the future in opal mining," she said.

"The fine print was always going to be the difficult part … what we wanted was to be sure of the future."

The decision to retain and expand the opal mining area ends months of unease. (ABC Western Qld: Hannah Walsh)

Ms Summerville said 47,000 hectares on the eastern and western edges of Vergemont had been protected from mining, but it was not considered significant opal-bearing ground.

The state government has also proposed giving small-scale miners access to an additional 155,000 hectares for prospecting.

The proposal would add 494 sub-blocks to the existing restricted area.

Boulder opals from Vergemont are sold around the world. (ABC Western Qld: Hannah Walsh)

Ms Summerville said she could not wait to reassure international opal buyers.

"This is a far-reaching industry.

"We have so many people who rely on us around the world, and I can't wait to get back out there and give them that assurance that we are there, we will be mining and producing one of the most beautiful gemstones in the world."

title: Cricket fanatic crisscrossing Australia on Vespa to attend every Ashes Test
text:
Scott Stokes is a man on a mission: to attend every Test cricket match in Australia on his little yellow Vespa — a trip encompassing 12,000 kilometres of open road.

Scott Stokes (no relation to England captain Ben Stokes) is a cricket tragic.

The 55-year-old from Canberra is crisscrossing the country for several weeks on his lightweight scooter to watch every game of the Ashes.

While some might choose to fly, Scott is doing it via bitumen at 90 kilometres per hour (85km/h if it's windy).

With the wind beneath his feet, he is making his way from Test match to Test match on "Van-espa" the Vespa.

But for Scott, the long, solo journey is also another type of test, as he grapples with his own mental health.

If you need someone to talk to, call: Lifeline on 13 11 14

MensLine Australia on 1300 789 978

Beyond Blue on 1300 224 636

"It has always been a dream of mine to go to every Ashes Test, both here and in England," he said.

"But the other reason is … it's a mental health journey for me."

Scott Stokes has had a "long relationship" with cricket, both playing and watching, according to his wife Helen. (Supplied)

In late 2020, Scott had a "fairly significant event" and was medically retired from his job in health.

"I bought Van-espa just after being retired and she's really great to ride, it's very good for mindfulness," he said.

When Scott floated the idea of an epic road trip to his wife, Helen, she "didn't say no" — so he took that as a green light.

"The Vespa has been kind of life-changing for him," Helen said.

The long journey, culminating in the realisation of Scott's dream to attend every Ashes Test in a series, has given him a target and a goal, she explained.

"I'm really happy that he's getting out there … he's definitely doing everything he can to rebuild his resilience, which has certainly been low in recent years," she said.

Scott Stokes with his mother Bev, before setting off on his 12,000-kilometre journey. (Supplied)

A 'bit of a dance' with trucks

After a short test run from Canberra to the Blue Mountains, Scott set out with his wife's blessing and a detailed list of petrol stations to ride the more than 3,700km to Perth.

"I followed him on a practice run from Katoomba and he didn't look like falling off … so I was pretty confident he's going to be fine," Helen said.

Contending with road trains, trucks, potholes and a petrol tank that only takes him a couple of hundred kilometres at a time, Scott successfully navigated the first leg of his journey to Perth for the first match.

Then, he jumped back on Van-espa for the second leg: Perth to Brisbane — a journey of more than 4,300km — for the second Test.

"It's a bit of a dance," Scott said.

" I have to be mindful of where they [the trucks] are. There's been a couple of close calls, which my wife won't want to hear about. "

Van-espa the Vespa taking a quick pit stop at the Mad Max 2 museum west of Broken Hill in outback NSW. (Supplied)

While Scott is a "fantastic driver", according to Helen, she has firmly ruled out a "his and hers" matching dual-Vespa scenario.

"I'm not very coordinated so we don't want me on the open road on a Vespa … I can just go on the back of his every now and then," she said.

That is, when Scott graduates from his P plates in April next year.

Until then, Scott has Helen and family behind him as he continues the remaining 4,000km journey from Brisbane to Adelaide, then to Melbourne (via the Great Ocean Road) and on to Sydney, before returning home to Canberra.

"We're about five years into his journey now, and it's tough on the kids, tough on me, it's tough on him," Helen said.

" But he's working really hard to do what he can to get better and you've got to admire that. "

title: $1.6m art installation, including 3-metre gorilla, gets town talking
text:
A 3-metre-tall bronze gorilla on the New South Wales South Coast is drawing crowds and raising eyebrows.

The artwork, Wild Mother Eastern Lowland Gorilla, is a statue of a 30-year-old eastern lowland gorilla named Mina.

Installed at Corrigan's Reserve in Batehaven, it is the second of 22 sculptures made by internationally acclaimed artists Gillie and Marc that will be installed across the Eurobodalla area over the next seven months.

Valued in total at $1.6 million, the sculptures have been permanently donated to Eurobodalla Shire Council through the Australian government's Cultural Gifts Program.

Mathew Hatcher said the gorilla and other statues were designed to spark conversation. (Supplied: Mathew Hatcher)

Pictures of the gorilla statue have been posted to local social media groups, with some commenters questioning the installation cost to council of $27,000 or the choice to feature non-native animals.

Eurobodalla Shire Mayor Mathew Hatcher said the debate the public art installation created was expected.

"Those noticeboards are lit up at the moment because of a gorilla and people telling you where [we] should have put it … [or] we don't have gorillas in the Eurobodalla so why do we have a gorilla?" he said.

" No matter if we put nothing or we put something, there's going to be people who are for and against it. "

Locals and tourists have been stopping in Corrigan's Reserve to take photos and admire the work. (ABC South East NSW: Toby Hemmings)

Mr Hatcher said the work was about creating a culture in the town and making it a space where people talk.

"There's no doubt people are talking," he said.

"It's getting engagement and that's what art is all about."

Conservation-based art

Known for their large public installations in major cities, Gillie and Marc are British Australian artists who make sculptures inspired by wildlife conservation.

In early November, their work The Splendid Fairywren Loved Adventure with Rabbitwoman and Dogman was installed at Nato Oval in Narooma.

The Splendid Fairywren Loved Adventure with Rabbitwoman and Dogman was installed at Nato Oval in Narooma in early November. (Supplied: Eurobodalla Shire Council)

The remaining 20 works to be distributed across the shire are a series of life-sized bronze sculptures depicting critically endangered baby animals.

In a statement issued via their publicist, Gillie and Marc said they were inspired to donate to the council after travelling to the region and being moved by its natural beauty.

"After the devastating [Black Summer] bushfires and the continuing pressures on habitat, we felt a strong responsibility to give something meaningful back," they said.

The plaque attached to Wild Mother Gorilla describes the animal depicted as a "peaceful queen". (ABC South East NSW: Jacinta Counihan)

Monkey see

For people who ventured out to see the work in person, such as Sunshine Bay resident Seamus Donegan, the reaction was more positive.

"I think it's good. It will attract people to the park and it's a good talking point," he said.

Graham Milliken likes the statue. (ABC South East NSW: Jacinta Counihan)

Local Graham Milliken said he thought the gorilla statue was "grouse".

"It's better than some of the art I've seen around, to be quite honest," he said.

"I'm not one of these abstract people — I'd rather see something like this than something I can't understand."

title: Five months' worth of food saved by team effort in remote WA
text:
A remote Aboriginal community has completed a mammoth 36-hour recovery of a food and supply delivery needed to feed its residents for the next five months.

The Punmu community, 1,300 kilometres north-east of Perth, orders a bulk food delivery every year to keep shelves stocked over the wet season, when cyclonic rains can flood the only road into the town for weeks or sometimes months.

Community coordinator Edith Costello said the triple-trailer road train carrying about $400,000 worth of food and supplies broke down 25 kilometres from the town early on Sunday morning.

Edith Costello says the community had to resolve the situation on its own. (ABC Pilbara: Alistair Bates)

"I realised we had to get together and make a plan," she said.

"We're probably the third-most remote community in WA, so there isn't anyone to call."

What followed was a mammoth 36-hour recovery effort.

Team effort

Rough conditions on the unsealed road into Punmu had cracked one of the truck's air springs and broken away a large mount on its left side.

Ms Costello sent out the community's mechanic, who did some temporary repairs and ditched the truck's trailers so the driver could take it slowly to the workshop in town.

It took 5 hours to repair the road train. (Supplied: Punmu Aboriginal Community)

Over the next 5 hours, the mechanic removed the left-hand back wheels and repaired the broken parts, before welding everything back in place.

"Meanwhile, staff were flattening and trying to harden the road section that had given way in the hope we could get back to retrieve our trailers," Ms Costello said.

Punmu finance manager Gary Kairn was tasked with ferrying diesel to the stranded trailers so the meat inside could remain refrigerated.

"I've worked in communities for a lot of years and it's really a matter of if you see a job that needs doing, you've just got to have a crack at it," he said.

"It does build a sense of camaraderie."

Gary Kairn (left) says coming together to tackle the problem built a sense of camaraderie among the Punmu team. (Supplied: Punmu Aboriginal Corporation)

When the repairs were complete, each trailer was collected and driven to the community, with the final pallets unloaded around 6pm on Monday.

"Seeing all the goods loaded into the warehouse and into the freezer at the end of the day was a fantastic outcome," Mr Kairn said.

Rescue reignites roads debate

The incident is further evidence of a road maintenance crisis the local shire has been pleading with state and federal governments to help fix for months.

The Shire of East Pilbara has been struggling with maintaining roads across an area larger than Victoria.

Punmu is one of Western Australia's most remote Indigenous communities, reliant on bulk food deliveries to keep people fed over the wet season. (ABC News: Charlie McLean)

It estimates almost $300 million is required to re-sheet worn-out dirt roads and repair damage from Cyclone Zelia last year.

"The road's been hammered by two cyclones … over the last month we've had a car roll over, we've had vehicles lose wheels," Ms Costello said.

"It's a very difficult road to drive no matter how careful you are."

Ms Costello said she could not understand why the state government could not invest in the Punmu road, when it had given $60 million to Gina Rinehart's Hancock Iron Ore to help seal a road between two of its mines in the same region.

"Why is the government putting money into that road while neglecting other roads which are vital routes?" she said.

" The route through our community goes straight to Alice Springs. It's a lifeline to us, not just for food but for essential services. "

Road conditions in the east Pilbara have been in the spotlight this year. (Supplied: Michael King)

The condition of the east Pilbara's roads has attracted attention from political parties on opposite ends of the spectrum.

The Greens' Sophie McNeill and the Nationals' Julie Freeman have both visited Punmu this year to advocate for more state funding.

"It's an incredible story how the Punmu community came together to save this critical food order … but it shouldn't have had to come to that," Ms McNeill said.

"These remote communities need to be better supported by our government, and the state of the roads are just atrocious and it's not viable."

WA Transport Minister Rita Saffioti was contacted for comment but did not reply ahead of publication.

title: Victorian government targets executives as 1,000 public sector jobs cut
text:
